Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1604241, Principal Investigator: Michael Kapovich

Groups appear naturally as symmetries of geometric and physical objects, like wall-patterns, minerals, snowflakes and, ultimately, the entire universe. This project studies relation between algebraic properties of groups and geometry of spaces for which groups appear as symmetries. Another part of the project deals with geometry of mechanical devices such as bar-and-joint mechanisms and gear trains. The project will involve rigorous mathematical definitions of such devices and analysis of possible motion spaces (configuration spaces) of the devices.

This project is a continuation of the principal investigator's research of previous years in the areas of geometry, topology, geometric group theory and theory of mechanical devices. The subjects of the planned research revolve around geometry of group actions on various spaces, geometry of buildings, interactions of algebraic geometry, hyperbolic geometry and geometric group theory. Another part of the project deals with geometry of mechanical devices such as gear trains. The goal here is to give mathematical definition of such devices, generalizing the definition of a mechanical linkage as a finite metric graph and proving a universality theorem for configuration spaces of these devices, namely that any algebraic partial differential relation can be realized as the configuration space of some device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Groups appear naturally as symmetries of geometric and physical objects, like wall-patterns, minerals, snowflakes and, ultimately, the entire universe. In this project Kapovich studied relation between algebraic properties of groups and geometry of spaces for which groups appear as symmetries, connecting several fields of mathematics: Algebra, Geometry, Topology and Analysis. 

The main outcomes of this NSF project are new results in theory of discrete subgroups of isometry of spaces of negative curvature. In particular, Kapovich gave negative answer to a problem posed by a Fields medalist, Gregory Margulis, in 1974 regarding an analogue of Selberg's Theorem.

In collaboration with Cornelia Drutu, Kapovich published an 800 page long book on Geometric Group Theory, proividing first textbook treatment of some fundamental results in the subject, frequently, with new proofs. The book also contains some new results, for instance, connecting Functional Analysis and Group Theory, providing geometric characterization of two analytical properties of groups (Kazhdan's Property T and the Haagerup Property). 

In collaboration with Leeb and Porti, as well as with his PhD student, Dey, Kapovich investigated discrete subgroups of Lie groups, developing an analogue of the classical theory of Kleinian groups; this research resulted in 8 papers (six of which were published). This area of research (Anosov subgroups of Lie groups, characterized by certain expansion properties) is currently very active and some of the results obtained by Kapovich and his collaborators were presented by Olivier Guichard at Seminar Bourbaki (this seminar is a actually a series of  public lectures with printed notes distributed that has been held in Paris since 1948. It is one of the major institutions of contemporary mathematics, and a barometer of mathematical achievement, fashion, and reputation). In a paper with Dey, Kapovich established a connection between the entropy (critical exponent) of discrete groups of motions of complex-hyperbolic spaces and complex analysis, proving that for groupps with small (that is, less than 2) entropy, the corresponding complex manifold is Stein, meaning that it has large supply of complex-analytic functions. In another joint paper with Dey, Kapovich proved results on ergodic behavior of Anosov subgroups. 

In several papers written jointly with his other PhD student, Liu, Kapovich investigated "chaotic properties" (dynamics on the limit sets) of discrete isometry groups of manifolds of negative curvature. In particular, Kapovich and Liu established lower bounds on the size of "non-conical limit sets" of discrete groups, but also show that in some situations, these limit sets can be arbitrarily small in measure-theoretic sense. 

Jointly with his students Dey and Liu, Kapovich wrote a paper establishing a quantitative existence theorem for "free subgroups" of discrete groups of motions of negatively curved spaces, answering a question posed by Cerocchi and allowing to strengthen his earlier work with Sambusetti on "counting" 3-dimensional manifolds. With the improvement established by Kapovich and his students, the "counting" now applies also to hyperbolic manifolds, which are in some sense generic among 3-dimensional manifolds.
